did.unittitle: Manuscripts
Short Story: " An Unfinished Poem"
" A Father's Letter to his Son"

scopecontent.p: [Includes book dealer's note.]

did.unittitle: " Pall Mall St. "

scopecontent.p: [Signed Wm. Pauncefoot Nye.]

did.unittitle: Poem beginning "The autumn leaves is falling . . ."

scopecontent.p: [For Miss May Smillie. ]

did.unittitle: Beginning, "This is a reading from one of my unpublished works . . ."

scopecontent.p: [Includes typed transcript; gives account of the first money he ever earned and a visit to the circus.]

did.unittitle: " The Autobiography of a Justice of the Peace"

scopecontent.p: [Includes pencil notation "Regular galley matter follows here" in an unknown hand.]

did.unittitle: Letters
Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Leon Meare

scopecontent.p: [Encloses "Unfinished Poem" in letter; mentions Mr. [Roshacher].]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Frank Hatton

scopecontent.p: [Includes typewritten dealer's comment and original pen and ink drawing by Nye; as former postmaster of Laramie, he congratulates him on appointment as United StatesPostmaster General.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "Friend Scott"

scopecontent.p: [Includes dealer's note; hopes to meet him in person on Nye's upcoming trip to Boston, having been acquainted with him for years in spirit only; accepts Scott's invitation to help him "destroy a chicken"; says he will stop on the way to Bostonto deliver a lecture in Altoona, Pennsylvania; mentions his uncle, B. S. Nye. ]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Samuel Sidney McClure

scopecontent.p: [Includes small magazine photo of Nye; indicates his readiness to do all his humorous writing for McClure's syndicate; suggests that it would be more profitable for both the writer and the paper; says that copyright would prevent his articles from being "stolen" by other papers as frequently is the case now.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Samuel Sidney McClure

scopecontent.p: [Agrees to write exclusively for the syndicate if conditions can be met, starting with $60 per week; asks the publisher to pay him whatever is fair for the material that has already been published.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to James Newton Matthews

scopecontent.p: [Relates how James Whitcomb Riley"secured the Metropolitan Pelt at the Author's Reading"; says Riley was not given a chance but was very convincing in introducing his own style of humor; states that the audience, press, as well as the critics were enthusiastic.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Walter Hugh McDougall

scopecontent.p: [Includes typewritten dealer's note; begins "Sir. You cannot scare me with your hot words," and ends "I do not seek a quarrel but the widows and orphans of those who has monkeyed with me agree that I am no slouch. Defiantly yours."]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Mr. Chambers

scopecontent.p: [Sends a piece that appeared in the Journalistand asks him to paste it in his scrapbook.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to John R. Clements

scopecontent.p: [Informs him that from now on he intends to publish his own books, starting with an Almanac for 1891.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "My dear Edward"

scopecontent.p: [Includes original pen and ink self-portrait caricature waving goodbye to ships; humorously commiserates with a friend who has shattered a foot; relates at length his own experience with a broken leg; says his after-dinner speeches at club have become much better since he took to drinking goat's milk and Vichy; says the speeches aren't as witty as before, but they read better in the papers.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "My dear fellow"

scopecontent.p: [Includes pen and ink self-portrait at top of page; informs him that he will come to the Author's Club; gladly accepts offer to spend the night at his home.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson ["Bill Nye"] Nyeto Mr. Kemble

scopecontent.p: [Looks forward to meeting him at the Emporium of Major James B. Pond; agrees to look at a manuscript with Kemble.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "Dear Sir"

scopecontent.p: [Announces opening of his new play The Cadion September 21, 1891, at the Union Square Theaterin New York City; declares that the expense for the production would be appalling to him had he to furnish the money himself; says the play relates to his own experience as a Justice of the Peace on the frontier.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Samuel Sidney McClure

scopecontent.p: [Turns down a request to do an interview "between me and myself" for the paper; claims that readers would not be interested and that he is pressed for time; suggest instead an interview between James Whitcomb Rileyand himself.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "Dear Boy"

scopecontent.p: [Humorous description of an accident he and his wife had.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to B. G. Brown

scopecontent.p: [Thanks him for a letter expressing regard and generous applause.]

did.unittitle: "Doe" to "My dear Harry"

scopecontent.p: [Sends on request an old Bill Nyeletter dealing with an injured foot; announces a visit to Philadelphiawhere he hopes to see Harry; promised letter is probably to "My dear Edward" from 1890 December 17.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to "Dear Leon"

scopecontent.p: [Extends an invitation to visit him at his home.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to unknown

scopecontent.p: [Fragment praising the music of his friend [Richard] Wagner, stating that it is much better than it sounds; sends James Whitcomb Riley's address.]

did.unittitle: Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] to Richard Watson Gilder

scopecontent.p: [Assures him of his readiness to write for him again.]

did.unittitle: Photographs and prints
Four magazine photos on one page of Edgar Wilson Nye["Bill Nye"] at ages 20, 28, and at the present day

scopecontent.p: [Includes 5 photos of George Washington Cableon verso.]
